Organization.name: Environmental Management and Planning Solutions, Inc.
Organization.fullName: Environmental Management and Planning Solutions, Inc.

Project.summary: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC (the applicant) is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, a 247 megawatt photovoltaic solar generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains ephemeral drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction of the proposed project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act. The US Army Corps of Engineers, as the lead agency responsible for complying with the National Environmental Policy Act, made a preliminary determination that the proposed project constitutes a major federal action that may result in significant impacts on the environment, and that the preparation of an environmental impact statement was required. The proposed facility would consist of a solar field of ground-mounted photovoltaic modules; an electrical collection system that converts generated power from direct current to alternating current and delivers it to a project substation; and a project substation that collects and converts the generated power from 34.5 to 230 kilovolts. The electricity would then be delivered, via a new on-site Pacific Gas and Electric Company switching station, to its existing Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kilovolt transmission line. Generated electricity would be sold to Southern California Edison under a long-term power purchase agreement.

Comments.content: The Draft EIS was distributed for public review and comment from September 11, 2015 to October 26, 2015. On October 6, 2015 and October 7, 2015, the USACE held public meetings on the Draft EIS. This Final EIS responds to the substantive comments received on the Draft EIS during the public review and comment period.

Project.summary: Executive Summary of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility Final EIS

The USACE’s proposed action is to make a permit decision on the permit application submitted by Panoche Valley Solar, LLC to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility in eastern San Benito County, California.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The overall project purpose is to construct an approximately 247 MWAC solar PV energy generating facility and associated transmission and support facilities in the west-central portion of California’s Central Valley (generally encompassing portions of San Benito, Merced, Madera, Fresno, and Kings Counties).

Panoche Valley Solar, LLC (the applicant) is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, a photovoltaic (PV) generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction of the proposed project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act.

The proposed solar facility includes ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system, a project substation, and a switching station to deliver power to the state electrical grid.

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: Panoche Valley, San Benito County, California

Project.summary: The applicant has applied for a Department of the Army Section 404 permit from the USACE to allow the discharge of fill into 0.1220.121 acre of ephemeral stream channels classified as waters of the U.S. The areas affected are Panoche Creek and Las Aguilas Creek on the western side of the project footprint and three unnamed drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. The project aims to construct a utility-scale, solar PV energy generating facility in the Panoche Valley region of San Benito County. The power generated by this project would assist the State of California and its retail suppliers of electricity meet California’s mandatory Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS).

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of a 247 MW solar facility. There are two no action alternatives: no build, where the solar facility would not be developed, and no USACE permit, where the facility would be built without requiring a USACE permit by avoiding waters of the U.S.

The USACE is neither an opponent nor a proponent of the applicant’s proposal. Decision options available to the USACE are to issue the permit, issue the permit with modifications or conditions, or deny the permit. The alternatives analysis is the heart of an EIS, and agencies must rigorously explore and objectively evaluate all reasonable alternatives. Reasonable alternatives are those that are practical or feasible from a technical and economic standpoint and using common sense, rather than simply desirable from the standpoint of the applicant. During the analysis, the alternatives developed for the EIS took into consideration the applicant requirements in siting a utility-scale solar generating facility, the overall project purpose as defined by the USACE, criteria related to cost, logistics, and existing technology, including the RPS and other federal, state, and local requirements, Section 404(b)(1) alternatives information submitted by the applicant, agency and public input obtained during public noticing of the project by the USACE in 2010 and public scoping for the EIS in 2012, and input from the USFWS and CDFW on project configurations to reduce impacts on federal and state listed species.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The applicant is proposing to construct an approximately 247 MW PV generating facility on 2,506-2,154 acres (project footprint). The project footprint is in unincorporated eastern San Benito County, California, approximately 30 miles south of Los Banos and 60 miles west of Fresno. The site is 2 miles from the Fresno County line and 15 miles west of Interstate 5 and the San Joaquin Valley. The solar facility and all associated land would be on property that is controlled by the applicant.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project involves interconnecting the Panoche Valley Solar Facility with the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line. Southern California Edison has a power purchase agreement to buy 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years starting in 2019. Telecommunication upgrades by PG&E, including optical ground wire and microwave communication systems, are required for system reliability.

The applicant’s proposed project preferred alternative involves constructing emergency egress and access roads that cross Panoche Creek, Las Aguilas Creek, and three unnamed ephemeral drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. Measures have been proposed to avoid, minimize, and compensate for impacts to waters of the U.S.

The applicant is proposing to conserve all lands in the project site that are outside of the project footprint to maintain and enhance habitat conditions for federal and state listed species. Approximately 2,514 acres interspersed throughout and next to the project footprint would be left undisturbed. Additionally, 442 acres of On-Site Conservation Lands contiguous with the project footprint would be placed into conservation. The applicant is also proposing to permanently preserve and manage two large ranches: the Valadeao Ranch Conservation Lands (10,772 acres) and the Silver Creek Ranch Conservation Lands (10,890 acres). These lands are being proposed as mitigation to offset potential impacts on listed species from constructing and operating the proposed solar facility. The applicant is also proposing to provide permanent protection and management of at least 1,000 acres of Additional Conservation Lands within the Panoche Valley.
Project.capacity: 339 megawatts of direct-current (MWDC) power, or 247 megawatts of alternating current (MWAC) power

Project.summary: Under Alternative C, a 247 MW photovoltaic solar facility with project features similar to those described under Alternatives A and B would be constructed on 2,500 acres within the Westlands Competitive Renewable Energy Zone (CREZ) in Fresno and Kings Counties.

Project.summary: The document provides an executive summary of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, highlighting scoping issues and comments related to biological resources, water resources, alternatives, and socioeconomics.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Comments.content: Most of the scoping comments focused on biological issues, especially impacts on sensitive and protected species, migratory birds, and grassland ecosystems. Commenters requested a full accounting of sensitive species, a thorough analysis of project and cumulative impacts, a description of measures to avoid, minimize, and mitigate project impacts, and provisions of mitigation, monitoring, and translocation plans.

The EPA and other commenters requested an estimation of the quantity of water required during construction and operation, the proposed source of the water, a description of water rights permitting and the status of water rights in the basin, the potential impact on other water users in the area, and the potential impacts on surface and groundwater.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a robust discussion of alternatives, including alternative sites, capacities, and technologies, and that an environmentally preferable alternative be identified.
A number of individuals had concerns over the impact the facility would have on the value of their property, local businesses, tourism, Panoche schoolchildren, and the community.

Project.summary: The USACE initiated a 30-day scoping period for the EIS on July 19, 2012, which was extended to September 7, 2012. Public scoping meetings were held on August 21 and 22, 2012. The scoping period ended on September 7, 2012. Twenty written comment letters were submitted by various agencies, tribes, organizations, and individuals.

Persons.name: Valentin Lopez
Persons.role: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Organization.name: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians
Organization.fullName: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Organization.name: Citizens Committee to Complete the Refuge
Organization.fullName: Citizens Committee to Complete the Refuge

Comments.content: Approximately a third of the comments focused on biological resource issues. The comments received during scoping were similar in substance and nature to those received during the USACE public noticing periods in 2010 and 2011.

The EPA requested that the EIS identify hazardous waste types and volumes, applicability of state and federal hazardous waste requirements, and mitigations that include minimizing generation of hazardous waste.

Commenters expressed concern about naturally occurring arsenic, pesticide residue, and potential for valley fever from construction-generated dust. Some expressed concern over potential soil and water contamination from the project. Commenters requested that the EIS address impacts on emergency service providers and waste disposal at the end of solar panel life.

Individual commenters expressed concerns over the levels and duration of construction-related noise, including that from post installation and traffic, the change in background noise levels in a rural environment, impacts on Panoche schoolchildren, and impacts on livestock and domestic and wild animals. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate operational noise levels.

The EPA requested that the EIS estimate construction and operational air emissions, identify measures to minimize emissions, and include a draft construction emissions mitigation plan. A number of individual commenters expressed concerns over construction-related impacts on air quality, primarily fugitive dust impacts from soil disturbance.

The EPA requested an in-depth cumulative impacts analysis, including identification of cumulative projects, geographic area, and temporal boundaries; current conditions, trends, and future conditions; parties responsible for minimizing impacts; and opportunities to minimize impacts. The agency also requested that the EIS evaluate impacts from the additional power supply and cumulative impacts associated with the transmission needs of other reasonably foreseeable projects. Commenters requested that the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on sensitive species from solar development in the region. Some commenters requested the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on waters of the U.S. and on species that depend on those waters.

Several commenters requested details on the applicant’s proposed project, made suggestions about the design and implementation of the project, or provided opinions on solar technology. Commenters requested that information on interconnection and transmission be included in the EIS, including requirements for upgrades. One commenter requested an accounting of acreage required for roads and conduit. Some commenters suggested the use of a more efficient photovoltaic panel to reduce the project footprint.

Commenters requested that the EIS analyze the potential fire risks from the proposed project and measures that would be taken to minimize this risk. Individuals expressed concern that the project would increase the risk of fire and expressed concern over firefighter response times.

Project.summary: The EPA requested that the EIS clearly describe the rationale used to determine whether impacts of an alternative are significant. The EIS should describe the current condition of the land, evaluate impacts on recreationists, and analyze impacts on Class I soils. The USACE submitted the Panoche Valley Solar Facility Draft EIS to EPA on September 4, 2015. The EPA published the Notice of Availability (NOA) of the Draft EIS in the Federal Register on September 11, 2015.

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS clearly describe the rationale used to determine whether impacts of an alternative are significant.
The EPA requested that the EIS describe the current condition of the land, if it is disturbed, and to what extent the land could be used for other purposes.
One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on recreationists, particularly bird watchers.
The EPA requested an evaluation of environmental justice populations within the geographic scope of the project and the potential for disproportionate impacts on these populations.
One commenter expressed concern over access to information by the Hispanic community.
One commenter requested that the EIS analyze impacts from the project on Class I soils.
Another commenter expressed concern over soil erosion.
Two commenters asked that comments provided to the USACE through the Section 404 public noticing process be included and addressed in the EIS.

Project.summary: The document discusses the environmental impacts of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, including various alternatives and their effects on aesthetics, dust generation, and lighting.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.name: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS describe the process and outcome of government-to-government consultation with tribal governments, address the existence of sacred sites in the area, and provide a summary of coordination with tribes and the state historic preservation office (SHPO), including identification of sites eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) and development of a cultural resource management plan.

The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians expressed concerns that the proposed project would negatively affect sacred lands and damage resources with ecological and cultural significance. The tribe expressed specific concerns on impacts on subsurface resources and requested that the applicant hire a tribal representative to monitor all ground disturbance activities, including the removal, repair, or replacement of any solar panel pole.
Comments.commenter: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: Individual commenters expressed concerns about construction-related traffic on area roadways, specifically the volume of traffic, hazardous road conditions, and degradation of already poor roads.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a strong rationale for the proposed project. The agency, along with several other commenters, requested identification of power purchasers and how the proposed project would help meet California’s renewable portfolio standards.

The EPA requested that the EIS adopt a formal adaptive management plan. Other commenters expressed concern that the project lacks a suitable restoration plan. Commenters requested that lands be identified to fully mitigate project impacts and that deferred mitigation not be allowed, that the EIS analyze the impacts of the mitigations imposed by the EIR, and that funding assurances and an enforceable schedule for restoration be included.

Individual commenters expressed concerns about impacts the project would have on local agriculture. They requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on local farmers, impacts from loss of grazing, and impacts on soils from solar panels. One commenter also stated that the valley was not farmed because of property owner choice, not because of irrigation inefficiencies or poor water quality.
Commenters expressed concern over impacts on the visual character of the area in general and impacts from light pollution on the night sky specifically.

The EPA requested that the EIS evaluate how water reliability might be affected by climate change, how climate change could influence the project, and how impacts from the project might be exacerbated by climate change. The agency also requested that the EIS quantify and disclose potential benefits on climate change from solar energy and quantify greenhouse gas emissions from different types of generating facilities. One organization requested that the EIS address the effects of global climate change on plants, animals, and habitats in the Panoche Valley as part of the future environmental baseline.

Individual commenters requested more information and commitment on the decommissioning of the proposed project, including setting aside funds for restoration. One commenter expressed the opinion that the facility not be decommissioned after 30 years but that the technology be updated.

Project.summary: The transcript of the public meeting and the USACE’s responses to the public comments received on the Draft EIS are included. Appendix A contains copies of the public noticing materials on the Draft EIS. Table ES-4 provides a summary of the potential environmental effects that could result from implementing the no action (no build) alternative, the no action (no USACE permit) alternative, and Alternatives A, B, and C. The on-site alternatives evaluated in the EIS incorporate applicant-proposed measures, EIR mitigation measures, and PG&E avoidance and minimization measures to avoid and reduce impacts resulting from construction and operation of the proposed solar facility. These measures have been committed to by the project applicant and are required as conditions of approval as part of the project’s approval and CEQA clearance by San Benito County. These measures are detailed in Tables C-1, C-2, and C-3, respectively, in Appendix C of the EIS.

Project.summary: The project involves the construction and operation of a solar facility in Panoche Valley. The environmental impacts of different alternatives, including no action, are evaluated. The proposed project would generate about 480 MTCO2e per year but overall would save approximately 155,460 MTCO2e per year compared to a fossil fuel-fired power plant. The project would help meet California’s Renewable Portfolio Standard and contribute to the implementation of the California Global Warming Solutions Act.

It highlights measures to protect vernal pool fairy shrimp, implement stormwater pollution prevention, and preserve vegetation communities. The installation of a single-span bridge at Las Aguilas Creek crossing under Alternative A would result in less disturbance compared to other alternatives. Overall, long-term impacts on vegetation are expected to be indirect and less than significant.

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves construction activities that may cause infrequent and localized disruptions of vehicle traffic due to PG&E telecommunication upgrades. Traffic disruption during overhead crossings of public roads would be minimized via a traffic control plan, resulting in less than significant impacts. During operation, the traffic generated would not adversely affect local roadways and intersections, leading to less than significant long-term and cumulative impacts.

The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves the construction and operation of a solar facility with various alternatives considered. The project would have less than significant direct and indirect impacts on housing supply, local employment, population, and environmental justice.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: Summary of Environmental Impacts: No Action (No Build) Alternative, No Action (No USACE Permit) Alternative, Alternative A (Applicant’s Proposed Project Preferred Alternative), Alternative B (On-site Alternative), Alternative C (Off-site Alternative, Westlands CREZ). Signs warning of electrical hazards would be posted. With these security measures in place, the risk of intentional destruction would be less than significant. Operational and maintenance activities could result in wildfire. The agreement with the San Benito County Fire Department would include such measures as maintaining vegetation to minimize ignition risk and ceasing all nonemergency work during a red flag warning. Because these measures are included as part of the no action (no permit) alternative, operation-related wildland fire impacts would be less than significant. Project operational and maintenance activities would minimally disturb on-site soils and would not create a risk of causing Valley Fever fungal spores to become airborne. As such, impacts would be less than significant. Potential exposure of sensitive receptors to hazardous materials during PG&E telecommunication upgrade activities is low. With measures to reduce fire risk included as part of the no action (no permit) alternative, impacts related to fire and emergency response would be less than significant. Cumulative impacts would be less than significant.

Panoche Valley Solar, LLC (the applicant) is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, a photovoltaic (PV) generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction of the proposed project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act.

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: eastern San Benito County, western Fresno County

Project.summary: The proposed project, referred to as the Applicant’s Preferred Alternative, involves the construction of an approximately 247 MW solar facility on 2,154 acres and the permanent preservation and management of 25,618 acres of conservation lands.

The applicant is proposing to construct an approximately 247 megawatt (MW) PV generating facility on 2,5062,154 acres. The project footprint is in unincorporated eastern San Benito County, California. The site is 2 miles from the Fresno County line and 15 miles west of Interstate 5 and the San Joaquin Valley.

Organization.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including measures to avoid, minimize, or compensate for impacts on waters of the U.S. Various steps will be taken to protect ephemeral stream channels and minimize ground disturbance during construction.

The proposed solar facility would consist of a solar field of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system, a project substation, and a switching station. The applicant is also proposing to conserve lands within the project site to enhance habitat conditions for federal and state listed species.
Project.capacity: 247 MWAC annually for 20 years beginning in 2019

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: Panoche Valley, San Benito County, California

Project.summary: The applicant applied for a conditional use permit to develop a 1,000 MWAC PV solar energy project on approximately 10,000 acres. Due to environmental concerns, the project was reduced to 420 MWAC on approximately 4,700 acres, and later to 399 MWAC to avoid biologically sensitive areas.

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Organization.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: San Benito County prepared a supplemental EIR to evaluate changes to the project since the EIR was certified in 2010. It included the changes described above and the actions needed to be undertaken by PG&E to interconnect the project to the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line. San Benito County certified the final supplemental EIR and approved the amended conditional use permit for the proposed project as identified in the Draft EIS in April 2015. San Benito County’s approved conditional use permit for the proposed project includes applicant-proposed measures and mitigation measures that are legally binding conditions of approval. This EIS incorporates those measures as part of the proposed project applicant’s preferred alternative evaluated in Chapter 3; the measures are detailed in Appendix C.

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: California, Central Valley, San Benito, Merced, Madera, Fresno, Kings Counties

Project.summary: The overall project purpose is to construct an approximately 247 MWAC solar PV energy generating facility and associated transmission and support facilities in the west-central portion of California’s Central Valley.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: Since submitting the permit applications in 2010, the applicant has revised the application to further avoid and minimize impacts on waters of the U.S. This would be done by reducing the number of proposed road crossings and by eliminating impacts associated with burying utility lines in trenches. Additional changes to the applicant’s proposed project have been made since the Draft EIS was published. These changes are the result of further consultation with or the issuance of permits by other regulatory agencies, all of which have reduced project impacts. The revised project as described is identified as the applicant’s preferred alternative in this Final EIS. Overall, the project footprint was reduced by 352 acres from the project analyzed in the Draft EIS. An additional approximately 93 acres of land within the two temporary laydown yards would also be converted to conservation land after construction is complete, yielding a total of approximately 442 acres of additional conservation land beyond what was identified in the Draft EIS.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The focus of the environmental analysis for each alternative includes the direct and indirect effects of constructing a solar facility. This includes short-term effects from construction activities and long-term effects from the presence of a solar facility. It also includes the effects from operational and maintenance activities associated with operating the facility, which are considered an indirect effect of the construction of the solar facility.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: Panoche Valley region, San Benito County, California

Project.summary: The applicant submitted a Department of the Army permit application to the USACE to construct the solar PV energy generating facility in the Panoche Valley region of San Benito County. The power generated by this project would assist the State of California and its retail suppliers of electricity to meet the mandatory Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) under California law. This law requires electricity providers to procure 33 percent of their electricity from renewable energy sources by 2020 (2011 Senate Bill SBX 1-2). The project would also assist the state to meet targeted reductions in greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2020 (California Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006 [Assembly Bill 32]). The applicant executed a power purchase agreement with Southern California Edison in August 2014. Under this agreement, the applicant is obligated to deliver 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years, beginning in 2019.

The document discusses the introduction, statement of purpose and need, permits, authorizations, plans, and the agency and public coordination and scoping process for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project.

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Comments.content: Public scoping meetings were held on August 21, 2012, at the Panoche School in Paicines, California, and on August 22, 2012, at the Veterans Memorial Building in Hollister, California. The meetings began with an open house that served as an informal question and answer session, followed by a formal presentation and oral comments. Eleven people attended the scoping meeting in Paicines, and six entered comments into the public record. Thirty people attended the scoping meeting in Hollister, and nine entered comments into the public record.

Organization.name: CDFW

Comments.content: Most of the scoping comments focused on biological issues, especially impacts on sensitive and protected species, migratory birds, and grassland ecosystems. Commenters requested a full accounting of sensitive species, a thorough analysis of project and cumulative impacts, a description of measures to avoid, minimize, and mitigate project impacts, and provisions of mitigation, monitoring, and translocation plans. The EPA and other commenters requested an analysis of the potential for habitat fragmentation, identification and analysis of compensatory mitigation proposals, and consultation with the USFWS and CDFW to incorporate lessons learned from other renewable projects and recent guidance to avoid and minimize adverse effects on sensitive species. Commenters also requested that the EIS analyze impacts from shading and alteration of rainfall on vegetation and species due to panel installation and impacts on species from pile installation and construction noise. The EPA also asked that the EIS include an invasive weed management plan. Several environmental conservation organizations identified the Panoche Valley as an important bird area, and some expressed concern that the quality and quantity of mitigation lands would not compensate for the loss of core habitat.
One commenter requested that the EIS analyze impacts from the project on Class I soils. Another commenter expressed concern over soil erosion.
Two commenters asked that comments provided to the USACE through the Section 404 public noticing process be included and addressed in the EIS.

The EPA and other commenters requested an estimation of the quantity of water required during construction and operation, the proposed source of the water, a description of water rights permitting and the status of water rights in the basin, the potential impact on other water users in the area, and the potential impacts on surface and groundwater. The EPA also requested an analysis of technologies that can be used to minimize or recycle water and whether it would be feasible to use other sources of water. The agency requested that the impacts on waters of the U.S. be identified and floodplains and stormwater flow be analyzed. Some commenters expressed concern over potential contaminants leaching from solar facility equipment.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a robust discussion of alternatives, including alternative sites, capacities, and technologies, and that an environmentally preferable alternative be identified. It requested that the EIS provide a clear discussion of the reasons for eliminating alternatives not discussed in detail, how each alternative was developed, how it addresses each project objective, and how it will be implemented. Both local commenters and nonprofit organizations asked to see alternative locations for the site, including in the Westlands Competitive Renewable Energy Zone; alternatives to utility-scale solar, including rooftop solar and smaller facilities located closer to users; and more efficient solar panels. Some commenters requested an alternative that avoided all stream crossings.

A number of individuals had concerns over the impact the facility would have on the value of their property, local businesses, tourism, Panoche schoolchildren, and the community. One commenter expressed concerns about housing impacts during construction due to the number of temporary workers. Some commenters expressed support of the project for the potential economic benefits it could have on the regional economy.

The EPA requested that the EIS identify hazardous waste types and volumes, applicability of state and federal hazardous waste requirements, and mitigations that include minimizing generation of hazardous waste. Commenters expressed concern about naturally occurring arsenic, pesticide residue, and potential for valley fever from construction-generated dust. Some expressed concern over potential soil and water contamination from the project. Commenters requested that the EIS address impacts on emergency service providers and waste disposal at the end of solar panel life.

Individual commenters expressed concerns over the levels and duration of construction-related noise, including that from post installation and traffic, the change in background noise levels in a rural environment, impacts on Panoche schoolchildren, and impacts on livestock and domestic and wild animals. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate operational noise levels.

Persons.name: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS estimate construction and operational air emissions, identify measures to minimize emissions, and include a draft construction emissions mitigation plan. A number of individual commenters expressed concerns over construction-related impacts on air quality, primarily fugitive dust impacts from soil disturbance.

The EPA requested an in-depth cumulative impacts analysis, including identification of cumulative projects, geographic area, and temporal boundaries; current conditions, trends, and future conditions; parties responsible for minimizing impacts; and opportunities to minimize impacts. The agency also requested that the EIS evaluate impacts from the additional power supply and cumulative impacts associated with the transmission needs of other reasonably foreseeable projects. Commenters requested that the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on sensitive species from solar development in the region. Some commenters requested the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on water supplies, on waters of the U.S., and on species that depend on those waters.

Several commenters requested details on the applicant’s proposed project, made suggestions about the design and implementation of the project, or provided opinions on solar technology. Commenters requested that information on interconnection and transmission be included in the EIS, including requirements for upgrades. One commenter requested an accounting of acreage required for roads and conduit. Some commenters suggested the use of a more efficient photovoltaic panel to reduce the project footprint.

Commenters requested that the EIS analyze the potential fire risks from the proposed project and measures that would be taken to minimize this risk. Individuals expressed concern that the project would increase the risk of fire and expressed concern over firefighter response times.

The EPA requested that the EIS describe the process and outcome of government-to-government consultation with tribal governments, address the existence of sacred sites in the area, and provide a summary of coordination with tribes and the state historic preservation office (SHPO), including identification of sites eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) and development of a cultural resource management plan. The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians expressed concerns that the proposed project would negatively affect sacred lands and damage resources with ecological and cultural significance. The tribe expressed specific concerns on impacts on subsurface resources and requested that the applicant hire a tribal representative to monitor all ground disturbance activities, including the removal, repair, or replacement of any solar panel pole.
Comments.commenter: EPA and Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: Individual commenters expressed concerns about construction-related traffic on area roadways, specifically the volume of traffic, hazardous road conditions, and degradation of already poor roads.

Project.summary: The document provides an introduction, statement of purpose and need, background and history, project purpose and need, and scope of analysis. It also includes an overview of lead and cooperating agencies, plans and permits required for the proposed project, and the public participation process. Additionally, it describes the organization and availability of the EIS and outlines the contents of subsequent chapters that cover project description and alternatives, affected environment and environmental consequences, statutory requirements, consultation and coordination, response to comments, list of preparers, references, glossary, and index.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a strong rationale for the proposed project. The agency, along with several other commenters, requested identification of power purchasers and how the proposed project would help meet California’s renewable portfolio standards.

Comments.content: The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a strong rationale for the proposed project. The agency, along with several other commenters, requested identification of power purchasers and how the proposed project would help meet California’s renewable portfolio standards.

The EPA requested that the EIS adopt a formal adaptive management plan. Other commenters expressed concern that the project lacks a suitable restoration plan. Commenters requested that lands be identified to fully mitigate project impacts and that deferred mitigation not be allowed, that the EIS analyze the impacts of the mitigations imposed by the EIR, and that funding assurances and an enforceable schedule for restoration be included.

Individual commenters expressed concerns about impacts the project would have on local agriculture. They requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on local farmers, impacts from loss of grazing, and impacts on soils from solar panels. One commenter also stated that the valley was not farmed because of property owner choice, not because of irrigation inefficiencies or poor water quality.
Commenters expressed concern over impacts on the visual character of the area in general and impacts from light pollution on the night sky specifically.

The EPA requested that the EIS evaluate how water reliability might be affected by climate change, how climate change could influence the project, and how impacts from the project might be exacerbated by climate change. The agency also requested that the EIS quantify and disclose potential benefits on climate change from solar energy and quantify greenhouse gas emissions from different types of generating facilities. One organization requested that the EIS address the effects of global climate change on plants, animals, and habitats in the Panoche Valley as part of the future environmental baseline.

Individual commenters requested more information and commitment on the decommissioning of the proposed project, including setting aside funds for restoration. One commenter expressed the opinion that the facility not be decommissioned after 30 years but that the technology be updated.

The EPA requested that the EIS clearly describe the rationale used to determine whether impacts of an alternative are significant. One organization described elements to be considered when evaluating the intensity of an impact.

The EPA requested that the EIS describe the current condition of the land, if it is disturbed, and to what extent the land could be used for other purposes. It also requested that the EIS discuss how the project would support or conflict with the objectives of federal, state, tribal, or local land use plans and policies. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on recreationists, particularly bird watchers.

The EPA requested an evaluation of environmental justice populations within the geographic scope of the project and the potential for disproportionate impacts on these populations. One commenter expressed concern over access to information by the Hispanic community.

Project.summary: Volume II of the EIS contains various technical appendices including public involvement, alternatives information, proposed measures, drainage crossing drawings, natural resources-related studies, biological resources documentation, agency consultation, plans, and incidental take permit.

Comments.content: The issues raised in the written comments focused mainly on biological resource issues, while all of the verbal comments supported the project for economic reasons.

Persons.name: Lisa Gibson
Persons.role: Regulatory Division, US Army Corps of Engineers, Sacramento District

Organization.name: US Army Corps of Engineers
Organization.fullName: US Army Corps of Engineers, Sacramento District

Project.summary: The evaluation of alternatives in this EIS provides the basis for the USACE to make specific findings under Section 404(b)(1) of the Clean Water Act. The alternatives evaluation must comply with both NEPA and Clean Water Act Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines for alternatives analysis.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE’s proposed action is to make a decision on the permit application submitted by Panoche Valley Solar, LLC to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility in eastern San Benito County, California. The USACE is neither an opponent nor a proponent of the applicant’s proposal. Decision options available to the USACE are to issue the permit, issue the permit with modifications or conditions, or deny the permit.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE has determined the least environmentally damaging practicable alternative for compliance with the Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines. The alternative must allow for the development of a 247 MW solar facility. The applicant has reduced the proposed solar facility from 1,000 MW to the currently proposed 247 MW facility.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE is evaluating two no action alternatives: constructing a free span bridge crossing over Panoche and Las Aguilas Creeks, and a no build alternative. A detailed analysis of an on-site alternative crossing technology that meets the overall project purpose is provided.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The alternatives information submitted by the applicant included a description of the applicant’s proposed project and alternatives in the following categories: off-site alternatives, on-site alternatives (alternative project configurations, energy output, and drainage crossing technologies). The USACE considered alternative on-site configurations, alternative off-site locations, and alternative technologies. The screening criteria used in evaluating potential alternatives for the EIS are described below.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The applicant’s proposed project has evolved through the San Benito County permitting process and CEQA analysis, and coordination with the USFWS and the CDFW. The goal in developing on-site alternative configurations was to reduce impacts on aquatic resources and sensitive biological species. No alternative configurations were found that further minimized impacts while still providing a project output of 247 MW.

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves the development of a 247 MW PV generating facility. The project includes an off-site alternatives analysis to meet Clean Water Act Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines and aims to avoid significant adverse environmental consequences.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project aims to develop a utility-scale solar facility to meet the 2020 RPS and deliver 247 MW by 2019 under the PPA with Southern California Edison. Various alternative sites and technologies were evaluated, but only the Westlands CREZ Alternative was carried forward for detailed analysis.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The proposed project involves the discharge of dredged and fill material into 0.1220.121 acre of waters of the U.S. The project is located in the west-central portion of the Central Valley, including parts of San Benito, Kings, Fresno, Merced, and Madera Counties. The project site must be within 2,000 feet of an existing 230 kV transmission line to be considered practicable due to cost, logistics, and transmission line connection requirements.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The applicant would build the proposed project, but in a manner that did not require a USACE permit. To account for either possible outcome, the USACE has determined that it is appropriate to evaluate both no action scenarios in the EIS. Under the no build alternative, a solar facility would not be developed at the proposed project site. Under the no action (no permit) alternative, Panoche Valley Solar, LLC would construct a 247 MW PV solar generating facility within a 2,506-acre project footprint. This facility would be similar to the applicant’s proposed project except that it would construct free span bridge crossings over Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks that avoided the discharge of fill into waters of the U.S. but still allowed for adequate emergency access to the site required by the Hollister Fire Chief.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The no action (no permit) alternative would avoid grading within jurisdictional areas on the eastern portion of the project site and use bottomless culverts to accommodate installation of the perimeter road. To offset the loss of developable area in the eastern portion of the project footprint, five 1.67 MWAC solar arrays would either be split into smaller blocks with less spacing between panel rows or would be relocated to avoid impacts on waters of the U.S. Relocated arrays would be moved to the western portion of the project footprint, requiring additional medium voltage switchgear and cable to be routed to the east side transformer in the project substation.

The project involves the construction of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility on lands secured by the applicant. The project footprint is 2,506 acres with an estimated maximum total permanent disturbance of 1,796 acres. The project includes solar arrays, perimeter roads, a substation, a switching station, and an O&M building among other features.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE has determined that a minimum of approximately 2,000 acres is needed to develop a 247 MW solar facility. This determination was based on a review of California solar facilities in various stages of development.

The project involves the construction and operation of a solar facility in Panoche Valley, including the permanent protection and management of conservation lands to mitigate impacts on federally and state-listed species. The project will also involve the discharge of fill material into waters of the U.S., requiring a Department of the Army Section 404 permit from the USACE.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The proposed project consists of a solar field of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system, a substation, and a switching station. The power generated will be delivered to the state electrical grid via PG&E’s Moss Landing-Panoche/Coburn-Panoche 230 kV transmission line.

The project involves the installation of high-efficiency PV panels within the existing project footprint without increasing resource impacts. The project includes a 20-foot-wide perimeter road for maintenance and emergency response, interstitial space for transportation access, electricity collection lines, inverters, and transformers.
Project.technology: PV panels, direct current collection systems, inverters, transformers, 34.5 kV alternating current medium-voltage collection lines

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, which includes solar arrays, project perimeter roads, a substation, switching station, O&M building, and various other infrastructure components.
Project.technology: Solar panels and associated electrical equipment installed on steel I-shaped support posts, with an inverter system to convert direct current to alternating current.

Project.summary: A substation and switching station would be constructed north of the existing PG&E transmission line on the west side of Little Panoche Road. Electrical transformers, switchgear, and related substation facilities would be designed and constructed to transform medium-voltage power from the project’s delivery system to the existing PG&E 230 kV transmission line. An operations and maintenance (O&M) building would be constructed next to the substation site to house relay, protection, and SCADA equipment.

The project includes the construction of an operations and maintenance (O&M) building, project roads, and access roads. The O&M building will be built on a concrete slab, providing operations equipment and parts storage, security, and site monitoring. Roads include a 20-foot-wide perimeter road with pullouts and additional transportation corridors for maintenance and access.

Organization.name: San Benito County Public Works Engineers and Administrator
Organization.fullName: San Benito County Public Works Engineers and Administrator

Project.summary: Emergency egress and access roads for the project would cross Panoche Creek, Las Aguilas Creek, and three unnamed drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. These crossings require multiple permits from various agencies.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of single-span bridges over Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks, with impacts on the Ordinary High Water Mark (OHWM) and surrounding areas.

The project involves the construction of a 20-foot-wide perimeter road for maintenance and emergency response. This includes grading to establish slopes for panels and control stormwater and erosion. Specific impacts on unnamed drainage crossing areas and federally jurisdictional areas are detailed.

The applicant submitted a Department of the Army permit application in April 2010 for a 420 MW solar facility. The applicant submitted a revised permit application in December 2010 for a 399 MW solar facility (the project approved by San Benito County in 2010). The applicant submitted alternatives information to the USACE in November 2012 and in December 2014 submitted revised alternatives information. The applicant’s current alternatives information, submitted to the USACE in December 2015, is included in Appendix B.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project involves the installation of a tracker system between solar panels, requiring grading and filling to limit the height of the modules above grade. Erosion protection measures such as riprap, concrete cut-off walls, and erosion control blankets will be installed. The project includes the construction of a culvert and low water crossings to manage water flow and minimize erosion.

The Panoche Valley Solar Facility involves the construction of various project infrastructure including perimeter roads, emergency access points, perimeter fence, maintenance transportation corridors, a substation, switching station, O&M facility, tubular steel transmission poles, stormwater control basin, parking areas, collector lines, solar array footers, and equipment pads. The project will result in permanent and temporary disturbances, with temporary areas being restored according to a habitat restoration and revegetation plan.

The project description includes the installation of low water crossings, grading and filling of jurisdictional areas, and the construction of security fencing with wildlife gaps. The applicant proposes to reroute jurisdictional drainage and implement erosion protection measures.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: The project includes the construction of fences, wildlife exclusion fencing, water tanks, and water treatment facilities to support the Panoche Valley Solar Facility.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves the construction of solar arrays, project perimeter roads, a substation, switching station, O&M building, graded areas, 230 kV loop-in TSPs, trenching and foundations adjacent to arrays, perimeter fencing, and a new Vasquez County Road.

The project involves the implementation of a stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) with various best management practices (BMPs) to minimize erosion and runoff during construction and operation. Utilities and communication services will be provided through local power grids, on-site generators, and AT&T services.

The project involves the construction of temporary ponds with a combined capacity of approximately 4,433,000 gallons to meet water needs. Peak daily water demand during construction is estimated at 1.72 acre-feet, with total construction water usage estimated at 385.15 acre-feet. A septic tank and leach field will be constructed near the O&M building, conforming to federal, state, and San Benito County requirements.

The project involves the installation of AT&T fiber and/or copper cables using a directional boring technique along public road shoulders and within the project site. Water will be required on-site during construction, primarily for dust control and sanitary facilities, sourced from the Panoche Valley Groundwater Basin.
The page describes the types of delivery trucks and construction vehicles used for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including the delivery schedules and vehicle movements during installation.

The project involves constructing solar panels in a general clockwise progression around the site over approximately 18 months. Construction is anticipated to begin in 2015, near the proposed substation location south of Las Aguilas Creek and west of Little Panoche Road. Emergency response plans would be developed in coordination with local, state, and federal agencies. Fire safety measures include maintaining vegetation at a height of less than 18 inches using sheep grazing and installing water tanks for fire trucks.

Organization.name: San Benito County Public Health Department
Organization.fullName: San Benito County Public Health Department

Project.summary: The project includes commissioning and maintenance activities, interior use of the operations and maintenance facility, and special status species impact avoidance. Construction activities are permitted from sunrise to sunset, with specific guidelines for noise and work during rainstorms. Site preparation involves biological surveys, species relocation, and road construction. Panel assembly and installation will involve transporting components to laydown areas and constructing the panels on-site.

The document details the construction traffic specifications and estimated daily traffic for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project. It includes data on peak and average trips, employee trips, material delivery trips, and total daily trips. The origin and travel distance for workers are also estimated.
The project involves the use of motion-sensor lighting at the O&M building and substation, estimated water usage for operational activities, and measures to reduce environmental impacts.
The document outlines various Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility to mitigate impacts on aesthetics, agriculture, air quality, and biological resources.

A prefabricated racking system would arrive on-site to be assembled and grounded. Preassembled PV panels would arrive on-site and be placed in a staging area inside or on shipping containers. Panels would be put in place manually and secured to the rack according to vendor specifications. The rack would be populated with panels, wired in series, and connected to a DC combiner box, which would deliver DC power to the local inverters. Equipment used for system installation would include 4x4 forklifts, all-terrain vehicles, truck-mounted pile drivers, cranes, and pickup trucks. Approximately 108 105 acres are planned for laydown and staging. Each laydown area would be at a convenient spot for construction traffic to access from existing roads. The laydown areas would require a power source for lighting, construction trailers, and parking. There would be no hazardous substances stored on-site outside of approved containment measures. The substation would be constructed by a contractor selected by the applicant, in accordance with its engineering, procurement, and construction contract specifications. The workforce at the project would vary based on activity at the site during the course of construction. Nighttime activities would have crews of 20 to 50 workers, and daytime crews would range from 100 to 500. There would be no on-site temporary workforce housing, and employees would be prohibited from parking recreational vehicles or trailers. All truck traffic and deliveries, along with approximately 40 percent of personal vehicle traffic, would enter the site from the north on Little Panoche Road. In order to accommodate the increased daily traffic volume and decrease safety risks to personal traffic, the remaining personal vehicle traffic would enter the site from the west on Panoche Road. Material deliveries and other truck traffic would be limited to using Little Panoche Road. Construction of the project substation or underground utility road crossings may require temporary closure or partial closure of roadways around the project site. An approved Traffic Control Plan has been prepared and will be implemented during construction of the project.

The entire project is expected to be fully operational by the end of 2016. The project would operate for at least 30 years, with the possibility of a subsequent repowering of the project for additional years of operation. The proposed project would operate seven days a week during daylight. Operations would consist of monitoring system status, performance, and diagnostics from the control room in the O&M building. System production forecasting and scheduling with PG&E and CAISO would also occur in the O&M building, along with operational planning. Operations would include meter reading and production reporting by the SCADA system, along with updating O&M manuals. Water would be used for sanitary facilities, fire suppression, and grazing livestock. In addition, to optimize performance of the proposed project, the PV panel surfaces may be washed up to twice annually during the dry season.

The applicant signed a large generator interconnection agreement with PG&E for the project in January 2014. This agreement confirms that the project’s electricity output would be deliverable to the transmission grid; it also specifies the interconnection and network facilities that would be required to interconnect the project with the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line. The applicant executed a power purchase agreement for the project in August 2014. Under this agreement, which is subject to approval by the California Public Utilities Commission, Southern California Edison is obligated to purchase and the applicant is obligated to deliver 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years beginning in 2019.
Final EIS for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility including various mitigation measures for land use, air quality, biological resources, and water resources.
The project involves conservation of 24,618 acres of on-site and adjacent off-site mitigation lands to address impacts on biological and grazing resources.

Project.summary: The project involves the purchase and permanent protection and management of conservation lands within the Panoche Valley. The applicant may choose to purchase conservation easements over 1,500 acres of conservation lands as an alternative. The project aims to preserve a total of 25,618 acres of conservation lands in perpetuity, including on-site and off-site mitigation lands.

Project.summary: The project involves habitat restoration and revegetation, enhancing regional connectivity for special status species, and ensuring grid reliability via telecommunications upgrades.

The document describes the installation of temporary guard structures and the crossing of existing transmission lines for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility. It also details the site disturbance associated with the proposed PG&E primary telecommunications upgrades.
Project.technology: All-dielectric self-supporting (ADSS) fiber optic cable and Optical Ground Wire (OPGW)

Project.summary: PG&E proposes to install new optical ground wire (OPGW) along 17 miles of its existing Panoche-Moss Landing 230 kV transmission line, between the new substation on the project site and the existing PG&E Panoche Substation in Fresno County. OPGW and ADSS would provide telecommunications services between electrical substations and generating facilities or other substations and would provide the primary telecommunication service for the proposed project.
Project.technology: Optical Ground Wire (OPGW) and All-Dielectric Self-Supporting (ADSS) fiber

Project.summary: The document discusses the avoidance and minimization measures committed by PG&E during the construction for the proposed telecommunication network upgrades. These measures cover various aspects such as aesthetics, air quality, biological resources, and cultural resources.

Under Alternative B, the applicant would construct the proposed Panoche Valley Solar Facility and PG&E would perform primary and secondary telecommunication network upgrades. Emergency egress and access roads for the project would cross Panoche Creek, Las Aguilas Creek, and three unnamed drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint that are subject to permitting under Section 404(b)(1) of the Clean Water Act.
Final EIS

PG&E proposes to establish a secondary system, which would be a microwave communication system that would achieve the same system protection. The microwave path would start at the project switching station, where a new 100-foot microwave tower would be constructed. The path would continue to an existing CAL FIRE microwave tower at Call Mountain, then to an existing American Tower Corporation microwave tower at Panoche Mountain. The microwave path would then terminate at a new 100-foot microwave tower to be constructed at PG&E’s existing Helm Substation in Fresno County.

Organization.name: CAL FIRE

Project.summary: The OPGW installation would be completed in approximately 12 to 16 weeks; at any one location the construction would take between 2 and 3 weeks. Existing roads and access along the transmission line would be used to install the OPGW, and PG&E would use the same methods when maintaining the electrical system. The locations of the pull/reel sites have been identified through a combination of helicopter and ground surveys and a review of aerial imagery. The criteria used in selecting the final pull/reel sites were accessibility for vehicles, presence of flat or nearly flat land next to existing transmission line route for equipment set-up, existing land use, absence of or minimal habitat for sensitive species, and absence of resources that would restrict work. Preparation of the temporary pull/splice sites would require some minor ground disturbance. Minor structural modifications would also be made to each of the transmission towers to allow splice boxes to be mounted where the sections of OPGW would be spliced (every three to five miles). The pull/reel sites and transmission towers would be accessed generally along existing unimproved roads or improved unsurfaced or surfaced roads that lead to many of the towers; no new roads would be constructed. Helicopters would be used to place materials at the point of installation for towers inaccessible by road. At each of the 75 existing towers along the 17-mile 230 kV transmission line route, minor upgrades to the steel attachments would be required to accommodate installation of the OPGW. These upgrades would include only overhead work on the existing tower, such as replacing the gode peaks with a pulley to accommodate the OPGW. The existing static wire would then be used to pull the new OPGW through each tower pulley. Existing roads or helicopters would be used to provide access to the sites to fashion the attachments needed on each tower. Construction would be completed using a combination of helicopter and ground crews. Helicopters would be used to transport electrical workers to the towers, to deliver materials, and to assist in pulling the OPGW from tower to tower. Approximately four 150-foot by 100-foot landing zones would be constructed approximately every five miles using means similar to pull sites. Establishing these landing zones would involve minimal temporary ground disturbance, and the zones would facilitate the use of helicopters and reduce overall impacts associated with the work. Landing zones would primarily be used for staging materials, picking up and transporting electrical personnel and equipment, and refueling helicopters.

The multi-span bridges have abutments near the top of the stream banks and support footings in the ephemeral stream channel. They are designed to have minimal backwater rise from a 100-year storm and provide maximum water conveyance through the site. Riprap or other bank armament would be installed along the footing installations to prevent erosion or scouring, ensuring the bridges are available for use by emergency personnel at all times.

The Westlands CREZ alternative assumes a 247 MW PV solar facility with project features similar to those described in Section 2.5. The facility would be constructed on an unspecified 2,500-acre site within the Westlands CREZ. The Westlands CREZ alternative also assumes that applicant-proposed measures similar to those described in Table C-1 would likely be applicable to the Westlands CREZ site.

Project.summary: The CDFW submitted an alternative access road plan to the Hollister Fire Department to eliminate proposed road crossings at Panoche Creek and Las Aguilas Creek. However, the Hollister Fire Department did not approve this alternative due to insufficient emergency access.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: Installation of the multi-span bridges would permanently disturb approximately 0.002 acre within the OHWM of the Las Aguilas Creek and approximately 0.002 acre within the OHWM of Panoche Creek. Placing fill for the two bridges would permanently disturb upland habitat of approximately 1,1402,280 square feet (0.025 acre). The bridge construction would temporarily disturb adjacent upland areas during construction. No waters of the U.S. would need to be filled for electrical cables in the multi-span design because the project would use overhead cables.

The Westlands CREZ has the potential to accommodate up to 5,000 MW of solar energy generation. Westlands Water District leases most of the Westlands CREZ to Westside Holdings for commercial development of the 24,000-acre Westlands Solar Park. The park is considering developing PV solar projects that are 200 MW or larger. CAISO has approved construction of a new high-voltage Gates-Gregg transmission line, projected to begin operation as early as May 2020 or as late as December 2022.

The project involves ford crossings at two jurisdictional ephemeral stream channels (Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks) and a cabled, concrete block mattress installation. The ford crossing alternative was eliminated due to its inability to meet emergency ingress and egress requirements. The culvert crossings alternative was also eliminated for similar reasons.
Project.technology: Cabled, concrete block mattress and multi-barreled, concrete box culvert

Project.summary: The document discusses various alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including the Moss Landing-Panoche transmission line alternative, the Panoche Ranch alternative, and the Firebaugh alternative. Each alternative is evaluated based on its environmental impacts, feasibility, and alignment with project goals.

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: A conservation and energy demand reduction alternative was evaluated in the EIR for the Panoche Valley Solar Project but was eliminated from detailed consideration. The project aims to construct a 247 MW solar facility in the west-central portion of the Central Valley.

The Natural Resources Conservation Service categorizes approximately one-third of the site as prime farmland. Hydrological features include creeks, drainages, canals, and approximately 14 miles of canals and drainages. The site also includes the Gravelly Ford Canal, which could be defined as a water of the U.S. The site contains potential emergent wetlands, and approximately 1,085 acres could be classified as jurisdictional wetlands. The California Natural Diversity Database indicates the presence of several special status species, including blunt-nosed leopard lizard. The nearest 230 kV transmission line, the Borden-Gregg to Henrietta line, is 12 miles east of the site. The Panoche Substation site contains approximately 4,085 acres of fields used primarily for row crops and has an elevation range of approximately 350 to 550 feet above mean sea level. The Los Banos-Panoche 230 kV and Los Banos-Dos Amigos-Panoche 230 kV transmission lines intersect the middle of the site.

The Brownfield-Kettleman City site was analyzed in San Benito County’s EIR for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility as one of several brownfield sites in the project area and was included in the applicant’s 404(b)(1) alternatives information. The site is an active commercial hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility operated by Chemical Waste Management, Inc., and owned by Waste Management, Inc. Approximately 500 acres of the site have been approved for hazardous waste activity and are degraded; portions of the site are undeveloped. The site is used as a disposal site, and the hazardous waste facility operator (EPA Identification Number CAT000646117) applied for a permit modification in October 2013 (CDTSC 2013). The California Department of Toxic Substances Control approved this permit modification on June 23, 2014, which allowed the site to expand its landfilling activities. This effectively eliminated any potential to buy or lease the property for the construction of a PV solar facility. The site does not contain lands within the 100-year floodplain, though it does contain ephemeral drainages in the areas of greater slope. The site may contain wetlands (USFWS 2014), potential waters of the state, though no jurisdictional delineations have been performed. The San Joaquin kit fox and blunt-nosed leopard lizard, both of which are federal listed species, have been known to occur on portions of the site. Developing the site would require significant grading because many of the slopes are greater than 5 3 percent. The area of suitable slope would not provide the acreage needed to accommodate 247 MW of solar power output. This alternative was eliminated from detailed consideration in the EIS because it was of insufficient size to support a 247 MW PV generating facility and it is not available for sale or for long-term lease. Moreover, it is a brownfield site and development would likely disturb potentially contaminated soils.

Organization.name: California Department of Toxic Substances Control

Project.summary: The project aims to construct a solar facility with a capacity of 247 MW. Alternative solar technologies and distributed generation were considered but eliminated due to feasibility and impact concerns.

Organization.name: USACE

Project.summary: The project aims to construct a 247 MW solar facility. Alternative forms of renewable energy like wind, biomass, and geothermal were not considered. Distributed solar generation, including rooftop solar and small solar facilities near urban load centers, was evaluated but not selected.
